posts.name: Umar Khan
posts.cooked: Hello, I’m posting for the first time on here because I am completely lost on why our auton seems to be accumulating error when pathfnding, and then correcting very very suddenly causing it to seem ‘jerky’ which messes us up farther. I am using a pathfindthenfollowpath() method to run autons and even now have been struggling with getting a 1 coral auton working using this method because of the fact that when the auton starts or when the auton switches from pathfnding to the follow path, it jerks very very aggressively and pathplanner records high error compared to the rest of the path (30 cm error compared to 0-2 cm). I was wondering if anyone else also had these issues. I tried to tune our translational and rotational pid controllers to make it better but it didn’t seem to have an effect. I also used to constantly be updating odometry using april tag reading less than 4 meters away and with an ambiguity less than 0.1, but after taking this out the problem seems to persist. Another thing that we tried was various max velocity and max acceleration values but we reached down all the way to 1 m/s for both values and 180 degrees/s for the rotational velocity and rotational acceleration and it still has not fixed the issue. There is nothing like this in teleop drive which constantly updates vision and previously in an attempt to have a teleop auto-lineup for placing using the same concept, although the project was cut quickly, the testing that happened with it did not show any of these same issues. I can also include videos and code for anyone interested or want to help in any way.

posts.name: Görkem Akyüz
posts.cooked: Hey there, we also had a similar problem, I’ll do my best to help out. if you could share the relevant parts of your code—especially the pathfindThenFollowPath() method, odometry update logic, and PID /trajectory configuration—we can take a more detailed look at what the problem is.

posts.name: Umar Khan
posts.cooked:
the chooser is then just used for a getSelected method and put into another sequential command with the other parts of the auton. This is where the pathfindThenFollowPath() method is called.

This is how I update odometry using vision.

this is the method called in the AutoBuilder config for resetting our odometry. It is from the Swerve Request class and this was brought from an example on github since we are using a ctre swerve drivetrain

lastly this is the AutoBuilder config method that we call which has the pid configurations. Please let me know if there is anything else I can provide.

posts.name: Görkem Akyüz
posts.cooked:
I looked through your code, and a few things stood out that might be causing the jerky motion:

Vision Odometry Updates:

Since you’re updating odometry based on AprilTag readings, it’s possible that sudden pose corrections are causing the robot to “snap” during path-following. Have you tried blending the new pose with the current one instead of applying it immediately? Something like:

Odometry Reset Timing:

Just wondering—when is resetPose() being called? If it’s happening mid-auton unexpectedly, that could also explain sudden jerks.

If you can share more about how pathfindThenFollowPath() works or provide logs, it will be easier to take a deeper look.

posts.name: Umar Khan
posts.cooked: I thought that it was the vision odometry updates as well, but we took that out for testing and it did not have much of an effect besides loss of accuracy but the “snap” was still there, as for how pathfinding works, my understanding is that it creates 2 different trajectories. One is a straight line while avoiding obstacles to the starting position of the path, and then the second is a trajectory that interrupts the first trajectory that makes sure the robot heading and angle match with the starting position which usually makes this trajectory look like a curve. And then once those two are complete it lets the manual path run. The “snaps” are happening when we are changing between the 3 different stages and when we initially start the command as well. Here is also what pathplanner defines for pathfinding but I am not sure if this is very useful since it is very short. https://pathplanner.dev/pplib-pathfinding.html Also resetPose() is called when running an auton and the ‘reset odometry at the start of this auton’ button is selected. We are not actually running an auton through the gui so we would have to call it manually if that is what we wanted to do but we do not since we are pathfinding so there is no predefined starting pose anyway. Also there is blending to some extent with the addVisionMeasurement method unless I misunderstood how ctre swerve integrate the kelman filter into this method.

posts.name: Görkem Akyüz
posts.cooked:
Hey! Thanks for the additional details. To better understand what’s happening, would you mind sharing a video showing the robot’s behavior, especially when the snap occurs? That would really help in pinpointing the issue.

I’ll take a closer look and try to help with the problem once I see it in action. Appreciate it!

posts.name: Umar Khan
posts.cooked:
I cannot take a video from our shop since I am on the road on the way back from a regional, but I can show you a video of our auton from a match and I think it is easy to see in this one.

I am on the 3130 ERRORs which is the far bot on the red alliance

posts.name: Görkem Akyüz
posts.cooked: Hey, first off, just to double-check – is the robot’s starting position set up correctly? I mean, is it intentionally placed at an angle, or is it misaligned by mistake? If the starting pose is good and properly aligned, then the issue might be with the PID tuning. Sometimes, even if the robot starts in the right position, improper PID settings (like a high P value or incorrect rotation PID ) can cause overshooting and jerky movement. If the pose is fine, I’d suggest taking a closer look at the PID constants for smoother movement.

posts.name: Umar Khan
posts.cooked: The starting pose should be fine if I understand pathfinding correctly. It should be reading our current odometry and then using that as a starting point so since there is not an actual predefined starting pose then there is no way to misalign. As for the PID tuning, there is a good chance it is that but I do not know how I should be tuning it for good movement. I tuned it twice at different velocities and accelerations but still it is acting like this. The way I tuned it is by making a new ProfiledPIDController object from wpilib for two commands, and then for one I made the robot move forward 5 meters and tuned using that while the other command I made the robot spin to 180 degrees and tuned based on that. Is there a separate way I should be tuning for better results?

posts.name: Görkem Akyüz
posts.cooked:
First, for PID tuning, here’s how it generally works:

Start with P : Set it low initially. A high P value causes overshooting and oscillation.

Tune D: Increase D to reduce overshooting and smooth the movement.

Adjust I: If the robot is slow to settle, increase I to correct small accumulated errors, but don’t set it too high to avoid oscillation. It’s best to tune the PID values gradually, testing the robot after each small change. Make sure to test for both translation and rotation separately if you’re using different PID controllers for each.

As for the snap issue, one possible solution is aligning the robot’s starting position parallel to the reef. This way, the robot will only need to move forward to the reef and won’t have to rotate around itself. It’s a more basic, somewhat primal solution, but it might be a good last resort if other methods aren’t working. This could help stabilize the movement and reduce the snap you’re seeing.

posts.name: Umar Khan
posts.cooked: yeah. I will retune it tomorrow when i can get back to the bot. The rotational factor did help at times, but the issue is that most of the snap is translational instead of rotational so it only decreases it but we still have enough to miss more often than not. I do suspect it has something to do with PID I just don’t know if it is poor tuning or something weirder.

posts.name: Görkem Akyüz
posts.cooked: Hey, how did the testing go today? Were you able to try out the PID adjustments? Did it help reduce the snapping issue, or is it still causing trouble?

posts.name: Umar Khan
posts.cooked: still got about 7 hours until I am able to get back into shop, but I will let you know how it goes. Hopefully this pid tuning goes better than before but I dont anticipate much changes unless there is something wrong with how I am implementing the pid values and I can find that since I have tried pid tuning a couple times now both in real life and simulation. I will give it a go again since comp gave me an idea of what to look for by watching other autons

posts.name: Umar Khan
posts.cooked: Just got auton working. PID tuning was the issue but not the way I thought it would be. The reason out PID values were so off is because we used a ProfiledPIDController to tune the chassis when pathplanner needs PID constants from a basic PIDController so it was very off. We retuned it and went from 0 coral autons to 2 coral autons in 3 hours. Thank you very much for the help.

posts.name: Görkem Akyüz
posts.cooked: Just saw this—glad you got it working. I didn’t expect the issue to be that either, but it makes a lot of sense now. Really cool that retuning fixed it so quickly. Congrats on getting those coral autons running!
